sites.name: Basel Minster (Basler Münster)
sites.description: Iconic Gothic cathedral with red sandstone walls, colourful roof tiles, and twin towers offering panoramic views of the Rhine and the city. Features Romanesque and Gothic elements, cloisters, and the tomb of Erasmus.
sites.best_time: Daytime (Check tower climbing hours and potential service times)
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Small fee to climb the towers (Martinsturm or Georgsturm). Views are best on clear days.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry to the main cathedral. Tickets for tower climb available on site. Allow time for security if applicable.

sites.name: Old Town (Altstadt)
sites.description: One of Europe's best-preserved and most beautiful old towns, featuring narrow cobblestone streets, medieval buildings, picturesque squares like Marktplatz and Barfüsserplatz, and numerous fountains.
sites.seasonal_notes: Charming year-round, particularly atmospheric during Christmas markets.
sites.booking_tips: Best explored on foot. Free to wander. Guided tours available for historical insights.

sites.name: Rhine River & Ferries (Rheinfähre)
sites.description: The lifeblood of Basel. Enjoy walks along the banks, swimming in summer (Rheinschwimmen), or take a traditional reaction ferry ('Fähri') across the river powered solely by the current.
sites.seasonal_notes: Ferries operate year-round (check schedules). Swimming is a popular summer activity (use a 'Wickelfisch' bag). Buvettes (riverside bars) open seasonally.
sites.booking_tips: Ferry rides cost a small fee (cash often needed). Free to walk/swim. Check water safety info before swimming.

sites.name: Mittlere Brücke (Middle Bridge)
sites.description: Basel's oldest bridge crossing the Rhine, connecting Grossbasel (Old Town) with Kleinbasel. Offers iconic views of the Minster and riverfront. Features a replica of the original bridge chapel ('Käppelijoch').
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Pedestrian-friendly. Great spot for photos. Connects key areas of the city.

sites.name: Kunstmuseum Basel
sites.description: Switzerland's largest and most significant public art collection, spanning from the Old Masters to modern art. Housed in three buildings (Hauptbau, Neubau, Gegenwart). Holds the world's oldest municipal art collection.
sites.seasonal_notes: Permanent collection may have free admission times/days (check website). Special exhibitions usually require separate paid tickets.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets can be bought online or on site. Check opening hours (often closed Mondays). Allow ample time (2-4 hours).

sites.name: Museum Tinguely
sites.description: Dedicated to the life and work of Swiss kinetic artist Jean Tinguely. Features playful, interactive machine sculptures made from scrap metal and everyday objects. Housed in a building designed by Mario Botta.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round, check website for hours.
sites.booking_tips: Located slightly outside the immediate center, easily reachable by tram. Tickets online or on site. Interactive exhibits are fun for all ages.

sites.name: Fondation Beyeler
sites.description: Internationally renowned museum housing the Beyeler collection of modern and contemporary art (Monet, Cézanne, Picasso, Rothko, Warhol, etc.). Located in a serene park setting in nearby Riehen, designed by Renzo Piano.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round, including most holidays. Park and temporary exhibitions offer variety.
sites.booking_tips: Located in Riehen (approx. 20-30 min tram ride from Basel SBB). Book tickets online to avoid queues, especially for popular exhibitions.

sites.name: Basel Town Hall (Rathaus)
sites.description: Striking red sandstone building dominating Marktplatz. Features elaborate frescoes, a beautiful courtyard, and ornate decorations symbolizing Basel's history and governance. Seat of the Cantonal government.
sites.seasonal_notes: Courtyard accessible during opening hours. Guided tours might be available to see interior rooms (check Basel Tourism).
sites.booking_tips: Located centrally on Marktplatz. Free access to the courtyard. Check for guided tour availability and times.

sites.name: Spalentor (Gate of Spalen)
sites.description: The most magnificent and impressive of Basel's three surviving medieval city gates (formerly part of the city walls). Adorned with sculptures and a patterned tile roof.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Located west of the Old Town. Free to view from the outside. Great photo opportunity.

sites.name: Zoologischer Garten Basel (Zoo Basel)
sites.description: Switzerland's oldest and largest zoo (by number of animals), known locally as 'Zolli'. Features diverse animal habitats, including an aquarium (Vivarium), monkey house, elephant enclosure, and the 'Ozeanium' (planned). Focuses on breeding programs.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open 365 days a year. Animals may be more active at certain times/weather conditions.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available online or at the entrance. Easily accessible by tram. Plan for at least half a day.

sites.name: Basler Papiermühle (Swiss Museum for Paper, Writing and Printing)
sites.description: Located in a beautifully restored medieval paper mill in the St. Alban district. Offers hands-on exhibits demonstrating paper making, typesetting, bookbinding, and the history of writing.
sites.seasonal_notes: Check website for opening hours (closed Mondays). Hands-on activities make it engaging.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets on site. Allow 1.5-2 hours. The St. Alban valley itself is picturesque for a walk.

sites.name: Marktplatz (Market Square)
sites.description: The vibrant heart of Basel's Old Town, dominated by the colourful Rathaus. Hosts a daily market (except Sundays) selling fresh produce, flowers, local specialties, and baked goods.
sites.seasonal_notes: Market operates year-round, lively atmosphere. Special seasonal markets (e.g., Christmas) held here.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Check market days/hours for full experience. Great place to grab a snack or observe local life.

sites.name: Vitra Design Museum
sites.description: Located just across the German border in Weil am Rhein, this architectural masterpiece designed by Frank Gehry houses an internationally renowned furniture design collection and hosts cutting-edge exhibitions on design, architecture and related topics.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with changing exhibitions. The Vitra Campus features buildings by renowned architects like Zaha Hadid, Tadao Ando and others.
sites.booking_tips: Easy to reach by bus from Basel. Guided architecture tours available (book in advance). Combined tickets for exhibitions and architecture tour recommended.

sites.name: Barfüsserplatz
sites.description: One of Basel's main squares, named after the Barfüsserkirche (Barefoot Friars' Church) which now houses the Historical Museum. A bustling hub with cafés, shops, and tram connections. Central location for many festivals and events.
sites.seasonal_notes: Major site for Basel's Christmas Market in December. Hosts various events and festivals throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Central location makes it an ideal meeting point. Surrounded by shops and restaurants.

sites.name: Historisches Museum Basel (Basel Historical Museum)
sites.description: Located in the former Barfüsserkirche, this museum houses Basel's historical collections, documenting the city's rich cultural history from prehistory to the 20th century. Features include medieval tapestries, the Basel Cathedral Treasury, and artifacts from everyday life.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Special temporary exhibitions complement the permanent collection.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available on site. Check website for current exhibitions. Combined tickets with other Basel museums may be available.

sites.name: St. Alban-Tal (St. Alban Valley)
sites.description: Picturesque medieval district along a water channel that once powered paper mills. Features historic buildings, remaining water wheels, small bridges, and peaceful walkways. Known as Basel's 'Little Venice'.
sites.seasonal_notes: Charming year-round, particularly beautiful in spring and summer when flowers bloom along the water channels.
sites.booking_tips: Free to explore. Combine with a visit to the Basel Paper Mill Museum located in this area.

sites.name: Messeturm (Trade Fair Tower)
sites.description: Switzerland's tallest office building at 105 meters, designed by Morger & Degelo and Daniele Marques. Located adjacent to the Messe Basel exhibition center. Its distinctive red facade has become a Basel landmark.
sites.seasonal_notes: Exterior viewable year-round. The Bar Rouge on the top floor offers panoramic views (check opening hours and dress code).
sites.booking_tips: While the building itself isn't open to the public, Bar Rouge on the top floor is accessible (reservation recommended).

sites.name: Messe Basel (Basel Exhibition Center)
sites.description: Basel's main exhibition complex, redesigned by Herzog & de Meuron in 2013. Home to major international events including Art Basel and Baselworld (watch and jewelry fair). The 'City Lounge' covered square is an architectural highlight.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open depending on event schedule. Art Basel in June and Baselworld (now renamed) are the most significant events.
sites.booking_tips: Check event calendar and purchase tickets accordingly. Located near the German border, easily accessible by public transport.

sites.name: Tinguely Fountain (Fasnachtsbrunnen)
sites.description: Playful kinetic fountain by Jean Tinguely, located on the site of the former city theater. Features whimsical, moving mechanical sculptures that splash and dance in the water.
sites.seasonal_notes: Operating year-round except during cleaning or maintenance. Most impressive when machines are active.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Located near Kunstmuseum Basel. Best viewed when the mechanical elements are in motion.

sites.name: Solitude Park
sites.description: Riverside park next to the Museum Tinguely offering relaxing green space with views of the Rhine. Features sculptures, including Niki de Saint Phalle's colorful works, complementing the nearby Tinguely Museum.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most enjoyable in good weather. Summer picnics popular. Art installations may change periodically.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Combine with a visit to the nearby Museum Tinguely. Bring a picnic in good weather.

sites.name: Theater Basel
sites.description: Switzerland's largest multi-genre theater, hosting opera, ballet, and drama performances. Known for innovative productions and high artistic quality. The modern building dates from 1975 and features multiple performance spaces.
sites.seasonal_notes: Season typically runs from September to June. Program includes classical and contemporary works.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended for popular performances. Tickets available online or at the box office. English surtitles available for some productions.

sites.name: Basel SBB Railway Station
sites.description: Switzerland's oldest international railway station (1854), extensively renovated and expanded. Features an impressive neo-baroque façade, modern interior with shops and restaurants, and serves as a key transportation hub between Switzerland, France, and Germany.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. The station itself is worth seeing for its architecture.
sites.booking_tips: Central transportation hub with connections to most parts of the city. French section of the station (SNCF) requires passing through customs.

sites.name: Museum der Kulturen (Museum of Cultures)
sites.description: Switzerland's largest ethnographic museum with over 300,000 objects and artifacts from around the world. Located in the Old Town with a distinctive modern roof designed by Herzog & de Meuron.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Special exhibitions complement the permanent collection.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available on site or online. Check for current exhibitions. Combined tickets with other Basel museums may be available.

sites.name: Elisabethenkirche (St. Elizabeth's Church)
sites.description: The most important neo-Gothic church in Switzerland, built between 1857 and 1865. Features impressive stained glass windows, a soaring interior, and serves as a cultural and interfaith meeting place known as 'Offene Kirche Elisabethen'.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Hosts various cultural events, concerts, and exhibitions beyond religious services.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Check website for special events and concerts that might require tickets.

sites.name: Rhine Swimming (Rheinschwimmen)
sites.description: A beloved local tradition of floating down the Rhine River, especially in summer. Swimmers use waterproof bags called 'Wickelfisch' to keep belongings dry while drifting with the current from Schwarzwaldbrücke to various exit points.
sites.seasonal_notes: Water temperature suitable from June to September. Most popular on hot summer days. Annual mass Rhine swim event typically held in August.
sites.booking_tips: Free activity. Wickelfisch bags available at tourist information and local shops. Follow safety guidelines and check water conditions before swimming.

sites.name: Basler Münsterplatz
sites.description: The spacious square surrounding Basel Minster, offering stunning views of the cathedral and the Rhine. Site of various markets and events throughout the year, including part of Basel's Christmas Market.
sites.seasonal_notes: Hosts Christmas Market in December. Summer brings open-air events and cafés with outdoor seating.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Combine with a visit to the Minster. Great location for photos of the cathedral.

sites.name: Hammering Man Sculpture
sites.description: Iconic 13.5-meter moving sculpture by American artist Jonathan Borofsky, installed in 1989 outside the Messeturm. Represents the worker in all of us, with a mechanically-operated arm that completes 100,000 hammer strokes per year.
sites.seasonal_notes: Visible year-round. Mechanical arm moves daily except at night.
sites.booking_tips: Free to view. Located near the Messeplatz tram stop. Worth seeing in motion.

sites.name: Pfalz (Cathedral Terrace)
sites.description: Elevated terrace behind Basel Minster offering the best panoramic views of the Rhine, the city, and on clear days, the Black Forest and Vosges mountains. Built over the remains of the Roman fort that was Basel's origin.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Most enjoyable in good weather. Popular spot for sunset views.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Combine with a visit to the Minster. Ideal for photographs of the Rhine bend.

sites.name: Kunsthalle Basel
sites.description: One of the world's oldest and most prestigious exhibition spaces for contemporary art, founded in 1872. Hosts temporary exhibitions of cutting-edge international contemporary art in a historic building.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with changing exhibitions. Particularly active during Art Basel week in June.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available on site. Check website for current exhibitions. Combined tickets with other Basel museums may be available.

sites.name: Dreiländereck (Three Countries Corner)
sites.description: Unique geographical point where the borders of Switzerland, France, and Germany meet, marked by a monument in the middle of the Rhine. The neighboring area features a modern harbor development with restaurants and walking paths.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Harbor area more lively in good weather.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Accessible by tram and short walk, or via boat tour on the Rhine. Restaurant options available in the harbor area.
